You must install a dictionary in order to use the Firefox spell checker. Follow the link below for an overview of the available dictionaries.

Once you have added the dictionary, you may need to right-click on the transcript here in the Melvin Editor and activate “Check spelling” in the resulting menu and select the appropriate language under “Languages”.
The words are visually highlighted with reddish dots below.

The Safari browser automatically uses the integrated spell checker. All you need to do is select the “Spellchecking” option in the Melvin Editor before clicking inside the transcript. However, it may take a few seconds before Safari highlights the first words.
The words are visually highlighted with reddish dots below.
The Chrome browser automatically uses the integrated spell checker. All you need to do is select the “Spellchecking” option in the Melvin Editor before clicking inside the transcript.
The words are visually highlighted with reddish dots below.

This accessibility statement refers to the current version of the State Act on Equal Opportunities for Persons with Disabilities (Landes-Behindertengleichstellungsgesetz - L-BGG) of December 17, 2014. The SHUFFLE project is committed to making this website accessible in accordance with Section 10 (1) of the State Disability Equality Act (L-BGG).

This accessibility statement applies to this website (www.melvin.shuffle-projekt.de). This statement explicitly does not refer to the other websites and mobile apps of the Hochschule der Medien or the universities involved in the project and not to the content of third-party providers referred to via external links.
This website is partially compliant with Section 10 (1) L-BGG due to the the following non-compliances.
The Melvin application for creating videos and correcting subtitles is not accessible to screen reader users or people who only use a keyboard.
We are working on the accessible implementation of the content mentioned above.
The homepage and the Melvin video player are accessible.
This statement was prepared on 28.02.2025. It is based on a self-assessment that was conducted on 28.02.2025. This declaration was last reviewed on 28.02.2025.

You would like to inform us about existing barriers or request information on the implementation of accessibility? For your feedback and any further information, please get in touch with our contact person:

To ensure that this website meets the requirements described in Section 10 (1) L-BGG, you can contact the SHUFFLE project partners (melvin@shuffle-projekt.de) by email and provide appropriate feedback.
If the Melvin project team does not respond to your request within four weeks, you may file a complaint with the National Center for Accessibility (LZ-BARR).

You can contact the National Center for Accessibility (LZ-BARR) as follows: schlichtung@barrierefreiheit.bwl.de , Tel. +49 711 123 39375, Address: Landeszentrum Barrierefreiheit, Schlichtungsstelle, Else-Josenhans-Straße 6, 70173 Stuttgart.
This procedure is free of charge.
The option of bringing an action against associations in accordance with Section 12 (1) sentence 1 no. 4 L-BGG is hereby mentioned.
Our website is optimized for the following browsers: Chrome, Firefox, Edge, Safari. Internet Explorer is not supported.
Didactic Recommendations – How to Use Melvin Effectively

Before starting video production, careful planning from a didactic, content-related, and technical perspective is essential. This ensures that the video meets the intended learning objectives and reaches all students effectively.

It is crucial to determine in advance how the videos will be integrated into teaching and for what purpose they will be used. What role do the videos play within the broader instructional framework? Defining this objective helps in designing the videos effectively.

Providing videos places more responsibility on students for their own learning. Learning videos should therefore foster strategies for self-regulated learning (SRL) and motivate students to engage actively with the content.

Depending on the purpose, learning videos can vary in length, but they should not exceed a certain duration to avoid cognitive overload. Empirical research suggests a maximum duration of 20 minutes (Brück 2023).

The longer the video, the more important it is to maintain a clear structure and include pauses to support comprehension. Planning recognizable sections (introduction, main part, conclusion) in advance is advisable. Creating a script, storyboard, or screenplay can help structure the content and voiceover effectively.

When videos are used as part of an Inverted Classroom model, clear incentives should be provided for students to prepare for deeper engagement during in-person sessions. If a video is assigned to a specific session, this should be clearly communicated, and students should have sufficient time to review the content and any accompanying materials.

If a video is intended to introduce or deepen a specific aspect, a short and focused microlearning unit (also known as a "learning nugget") may be appropriate. These concise videos effectively present knowledge in just a few minutes. Multiple microlearning units can be organized into a series, with clear titles and sequencing information to enhance clarity.
A video on how to effectively search for academic articles in databases.
A video explaining proper scientific citation methods.

Is the video intended for one-time use, or should it be accessible across multiple semesters or courses? For long-term use, prioritize general and broadly applicable information while minimizing temporary references (e.g., links to potentially outdated websites).
Example: A video explaining the fundamentals of qualitative or quantitative research methods in social sciences.
Ensuring Accessibility – Universal Design for Learning (UDL)/Multi-Sensory Design Principle

To promote accessibility, information should be presented in multiple formats—for example, through both auditory and visual means. Tools like Melvin, which automatically generate subtitles and transcripts, can facilitate this approach.

All essential visual elements used in the video should also be described verbally. Ideally, the key content of an image or figure should be integrated into the spoken text. If this is not feasible, a separate audio or text-based description should be provided as an additional resource.
When combining videos with other digital learning formats such as text, images, or interactive tools, ensure that all materials comply with accessibility standards.
See document Tips for Accessible Tools
Each video should address a well-defined topic, clearly stated at the beginning. A precise title enhances recognizability and helps students navigate the content effectively.
Each video should specify its learning objectives at the beginning and in the course syllabus. This improves transparency and aids students in organizing their knowledge acquisition.

If a video covers content relevant to exams, this should be explicitly stated in the learning objectives. Additionally, providing practice questions can help students gain confidence in exam situations.
Integrating interactive elements, such as exercises, can promote active learning and deeper engagement with the material.
Where can students test their newly acquired knowledge? Quizzes or targeted exercises can be embedded in the video or incorporated into follow-up in-person sessions.
Complex concepts or technical terminology should be clearly explained, with references to additional resources (e.g., central websites or literature) when necessary.

Videos can include reflection questions or closing exercises to reinforce learning. Opportunities for feedback and discussion can be facilitated through digital learning platforms or in subsequent in-person sessions.

Both image and sound quality should be optimal, with good lighting and a distraction-free recording environment. A calm and clear speaking style, with sufficient pauses, enhances comprehensibility. A neutral background helps keep the focus on the content.

Reliable technical equipment and pre-recording checks ensure smoother production. Test recordings can help identify optimal settings. Depending on the setup, using two monitors may facilitate the recording process.
The video file name should be meaningful and include key information such as title, author, topic, and date.
Learning videos should be easily accessible on the learning platform. An accompanying syllabus summarizing the video’s content in bullet points enhances clarity and transparency.
Melvin is part of the SHUFFLE project funded by the Stiftung Innovation in der Hochschullehre. Three other universities are involved in the project under the direction of the Hochschule der Medien:
Hochschule der Medien Stuttgart is a body under public law. It is legally represented by the Rector Prof. Dr. Alexander W. Roos.

The author (provider of this website) assumes no liability for the topicality, correctness, completeness or quality of the information provided. Liability claims against the author relating to material or immaterial damage caused by the use or non-use of the information provided or by the use of incorrect or incomplete information are fundamentally excluded, unless there is evidence of wilful intent or gross negligence on the part of the author. All content is subject to change and non-binding. The author expressly reserve the right to change, supplement or delete parts of the pages or the entire website without prior notice or to cease publication temporarily or permanently.

In the case of direct or indirect references to external websites ("links") that lie outside the author's area of responsibility, a liability obligation would only come into force in the event that the author is aware of the content and it would be technically possible and reasonable for him to prevent use in the event of illegal content. The author hereby expressly declares that no illegal content was recognizable on the linked pages at the time the links were created. The author has no influence whatsoever on the current and future design, content or authorship of the linked pages. The author therefore expressly distances himself from all contents of all linked pages that were changed after the link was created. This statement applies to all links and references set within the author's own website as well as to third-party entries in guest books, discussion forums and mailing lists set up by the author. Liability for illegal, incorrect or incomplete content and in particular for damages resulting from the use or non-use of such information lies solely with the provider of the page to which reference is made, and not with the person who merely refers to the respective publication via links.

The author makes every effort to respect the copyright of the graphics, sound documents, video sequences and texts used in all publications, to use graphics, sound documents, video sequences and texts created by themselves or to use license-free graphics, sound documents, video sequences and texts.

All brand names and trademarks mentioned on the website and potentially protected by third parties are subject without restriction to the regulations of the applicable trademark law and the ownership rights of the respective registered owners. The mere mention of a trademark does not imply that it is not protected by third-party rights! The copyright for published objects created by the author or author himself remains solely with the author/authors of the pages or texts and contents. Reproduction or use of such graphics, audio documents, video sequences and texts in other electronic or printed publications is not permitted without the express consent of the author(s).

This disclaimer is to be regarded as part of the internet publication which you were referred from. If sections or individual terms of this statement are not legal or correct, the content or validity of the other parts remain uninfluenced by this fact.
Source: www.Juraforum.de - Legal portal with lawyer search as at: August 2017
Melvin is an open source project. As such, you can install and use the application on your own server. Follow the GitHub link below for the installation instructions:
CPU can be used for ASR, but is significantly slower.
Melvin uses ffmpeg to convert videos. Having multiple CPU cores available increases processing speed, particularly for long videos with high resolution.
A one-hour video is approximately 1 GB in size
Foundation 'Stiftung Innovation in der Hochschullehre', opens in new tab
Forgot password is disabled for this app, please contact an administrator
A password reset email has been sent. You can now close this window.
No user found with that email
Start your recording directly in the browser, without any additional software. Plus, you have complete control over which audio and video sources you want to use.
You already have a recording? Simply upload it and use it too.
After recording, your videos are automatically transcribed and subtitles are created. Using the editor, you can then make the final corrections manually, either alone or together with others.
Your recording can now be shared with our accessible player. You can simply share the link or embed the player in your website.
Of course, you can also download your files and upload them elsewhere.
This sitemap lists all pages that do not require a login in alphabetical order.

The following videos show an earlier version of the web application. Minor differences – such as labels or element positions – may therefore occur. However, they still provide reliable guidance. The respective text versions have been updated and reflect the current state.
With Melvin, you can record new videos directly in your browser or upload existing ones.
Click on “New Project” above your project list and select “Recorder” from the drop-down menu.
You are now on the recorder page. Add your desired input sources here (e.g., microphone, camera, or screen). At least one audio source and one video or screen source are required to start recording.

The browser will request permission the first time. Allow access when prompted. If no prompt appears, search online for: “[Your browser, e.g., Firefox] [microphone / camera / screen] allow permissions”
The audio level indicator shows whether your microphone is picking up sound.
Start recording by clicking “Start recording”. Please note that you cannot add or remove input sources during the recording.

After clicking “Stop recording”, the “Project Creation” dialog opens automatically. Specify the primary language of the recording to enable file upload and initiate project creation. To save individual files locally, use the download button located beside each file.
If you experience upload issues, save the video locally and use the “Upload Existing Video” function later (see below).
Once the project is created, your recording will appear in the project list. Processing may take some time depending on the video length.
Click on “New Project” above your project list and select “Upload File” from the drop-down menu.
In the “New Project” dialog that appears, you can drag and drop files or use the “Select Files” button to upload one or more files from your computer.
For each file, select a category and language.
Check “Use Audio” for the file that should be transcribed and used as the audio track.
Set a project title and click “Create Project”.
Your project will now appear in the project list. Processing may take some time.
To edit a project transcript, select a project from the project list. Click the project title or the “Edit” button.
You are now in the editor. Click the project name at the top left to rename it.
Edit the transcript directly in the text field. You can navigate the video using the audio waveform.
If a speaker change was not detected, press Enter to create a new paragraph and assign the new speaker. Paragraphs can be merged using Backspace. To change the speaker, click on the name.
Click the “Share” button in the top right corner of the editor.
Enter the person's email address and click “Invite”. If they already have a Melvin account, they’ll be added immediately. Otherwise, an email invitation will be sent.
Alternatively, use “Copy Link” to generate a shareable link that allows anonymous collaboration on the project.
A transcript in the video's primary language is automatically created for each project. To offer subtitles and transcripts in multiple languages, you can add more transcripts to a project.
Click on “Transcription” below the project name in the editor.
Here, you'll see all available transcripts and options to “Add Transcription” or “Edit Transcription”.
Clicking “Edit Transcriptions” opens a dialog showing all current transcripts. You can download, delete, or edit them using the “More” button (three dots).
Use “Add Transcript” to upload or copy transcripts.
Click the “Watch” button in the project list to open the project in the player (in a new browser tab).
Below the video are various buttons to control and configure the player. Hover over a button to see its function, or use the Tab key to navigate to it.
Use the “Language menu” to show/hide and customize the subtitles and the transcript. For more options, click “Settings” to open the settings dialog.
If your project contains multiple videos, you can manage them using the “Video Selection menu” button, located below the video next to the “Languages menu”.
Use the transcript to navigate the video: clicking a sentence jumps to the corresponding point in the video.
You can easily share your videos using the integrated, accessible player:
In the project list, click the “Watch” button for your project. The video will open in a new tab using the player.
Copy the browser URL to share the video.
Alternatively, you can embed the video with the player into your website using an iframe.
In the project list, click the “More” button of the project and select “Share”. The sharing dialog will open.
Under the “Share videoplayer” tab, click “Copy” to copy the embed code to your clipboard.
Example text: This is what the subtitles will look like.

This application is currently under development. Unexpected errors may therefore occur. You can find more information on the SHUFFLE research project website. If you have any feedback or questions, you will also find a contact option there.
Use arrow keys to resize the videos
The project is no longer available under this link. The access link may have been changed or the project may no longer exist.
You have been removed from the opened project.
The opened transcript was deleted and another one selected.
| Please try the transcription creation again.
| Please wait for the transcript to be ready for editing.
To ensure a more accurate timing of the translation, the transcript should be structured into paragraphs.

No, Melvin currently does not offer any editing or trimming functionality. However, recordings can be edited using an external video editor before being uploaded to Melvin. Depending on the development team's capacity and priorities, editing features may be added in future versions of Melvin.
Currently, this functionality is not supported by Melvin or web browsers.

However, you can use external software to blur your webcam background before recording. For example, you can use OBS Studio with a virtual camera or other webcam software that supports background blurring.
If you're using a Mac with Apple silicon and macOS Sequoia or later, you can change your background using the built-in functionality of the operating system.
Can I trim or edit recordings?
Can I blur the background of my webcam in the recorder?

Digitisation in education must not become an end in itself. The aim of concepts for digital teaching and learning should be to enhance the quality of teaching, improve its effectiveness, and at the same time promote equal opportunities within the higher education system.

So far, however, the topics of equal opportunities, inclusion, and digitalisation have rarely been considered in conjunction – especially not from a subject-didactic perspective. While digital tools offer a wide range of possible applications, not everything that is technically feasible is also didactically meaningful or accessible.

Melvin, a video platform for teaching, is also first and foremost a tool that offers various functions and creative possibilities. However, what really matters is how these possibilities are implemented from a didactic point of view. Through careful planning and thoughtful use, it is possible to ensure accessible and equitable access to content for all users.
The didactic guidelines provided here are intended to support teaching staff in using Melvin in ways that are both inclusive and didactically effective.
